		<script>
			(function() {
				var query_string, query_vars, utm_source, utm_medium, utm_term, utm_content, utm_campaign, i, l, keyval, utm_cookie;

				// check query
				query_string = window.location.search.substring(1);
				query_vars   = query_string.split('&');

				utm_source = utm_medium = utm_term = utm_content = utm_campaign = '';
				for (i = 0, l = query_vars.length; i < l; i++) {
					keyval = query_vars[i].split('=');

					if (undefined !== keyval[0] && undefined !== keyval[1]) {
						if ('utm_source' === keyval[0]) {
							utm_source = keyval[1];
						}
						else if ('utm_medium' === keyval[0]) {
							utm_medium = keyval[1];
						}
						else if ('utm_term' === keyval[0]) {
							utm_term = keyval[1];
						}
						else if ('utm_content' === keyval[0]) {
							utm_content = keyval[1];
						}
						else if ('utm_campaign' === keyval[0]) {
							utm_campaign = keyval[1];
						}
					}
				}

				if (utm_source || utm_medium || utm_term || utm_content || utm_campaign) { // try for new
					window.dt_utm_data = {
						utm_source:   utm_source,
						utm_medium:   utm_medium,
						utm_term:     utm_term,
						utm_content:  utm_content,
						utm_campaign: utm_campaign
					};

					document.cookie = 'dt_utm='+JSON.stringify(window.dt_utm_data)+'; expires=0; path=/';
				}
				else { // try for old
					utm_cookie = (result = new RegExp('(?:^|; )'+encodeURIComponent('dt_utm')+'=([^;]*)').exec(document.cookie)) ? (result[1]) : null;

					if (utm_cookie) {
						window.dt_utm_data = JSON.parse(utm_cookie);
					}
				}
			})();
		</script>

						<div class="sign-up"></div> \
						<div class="cancel"></div> \
						<a href="http://www.digitaltrends.com" class="success-link"></a> \
					</div>'
			});

			this.setupHandlers();

		},

		kitInterstitial: function(source){

			$.fancybox.open({
				padding: 0,
				type: 'html',
				closeBtn: true,
				closeClick: false,
				wrapCSS: 'dtwp2119-ni-container',
				content: ' \
					<div class="dtwp2119-newsletter-interstitial kit h-kit-interstitial" data-source="'+source+'"> \
						<input type="text" class="email-input" placeholder="Enter Your Email Here"/> \
						<div class="deals-too checked"></div> \
						<div class="sign-up"></div> \
						<div class="cancel"></div> \
						<a href="http://www.digitaltrends.com" class="success-link"></a> \
					</div>'
			});

			this.setupHandlers();

		},

		setupHandlers: function(){

			var self = this;
			this.$interstitial = $('.dtwp2119-newsletter-interstitial');

			this.$interstitial.find('.deals-too').on('click', function(){

				if( self.loading ){
					return;
				}

				var $this = $( this );

				if( $this.hasClass('checked' ) ){
					$this.removeClass('checked');
				}
				else {
					$this.addClass('checked');
				}
			});

			this.$interstitial.find('.cancel').on('click', function(){

				if( self.loading ){
					return;
				}

				var $close = $('.fancybox-close');
				if( $close.length ){
					$close.trigger( 'click' );
				}
			});

			this.$interstitial.find('.sign-up').on('click', function(){

				if( self.loading ){
					return;
				}

				self.handleSubmit();
			});

		},

		handleSubmit: function(){

			if( !this.$interstitial.length ){
				return;
			}

			var self = this;
			var $interstitial = this.$interstitial;
			var email = $interstitial.find( '.email-input' ).val() || '';
			var source = $interstitial.data( 'source' ) || '';
			var deals_too = $interstitial.find( '.deals-too' ).hasClass( 'checked' );
			var lists = [ 'DT Newsletter' ];
			if( deals_too ){
				lists.push( 'DT Deals Newsletter' );
			}

			var args = {
				action: 'dt_newsletter_register_by_email',
				dt_newsletter_register_email: email,
				dt_newsletter_source: source,
				dt_lists: lists
			};

			this.goLoading();
			$.get( ajaxurl, args ).done( function( response ) {
				self.stopLoading();
				if( response.status == "OK" ){
					self.goSuccess();
					vent.trigger( 'dt:newsletter:email_registered', email, source, lists, $interstitial );
				}
				else {
					self.goFailure();
				}
			});
		},

		goLoading: function(){
			this.loading = true;
			this.$interstitial.css('opacity','.3');
		},

		stopLoading: function(){
			this.loading = false;
			this.$interstitial.css('opacity','1');
		},

		goSuccess: function(){
			this.$interstitial.removeClass( 'failure' );
			this.$interstitial.addClass( 'success' );
			$('.fancybox-close').css('visibility','visible');
		},

		goFailure: function(){
			this.$interstitial.addClass( 'failure' );
		}
	};

})(jQuery, DTEvent);

</script>

		<div class="l-content-wrap h-multistitch-content-wrap">
			<article class="m-content m-multistitch-content alpha " itemprop="articleBody" data-scope="content">
				<div class='m-above-content-banner'><a href='http://www.digitaltrends.com/topic/ask-an-expert/'><img src="http://icdn9.digitaltrends.com/image/ask-an-expert-280x75.png" class="dt-above-content-banner"/></a></div><p>“It’s looking increasingly likely that cellular phones (mostly smartphones these days) are harmful in terms of cancer risk, particularly to the head and neck,” says Joel M. Moskowitz, Director of the Center for Family and Community Health at the University of California at Berkeley. “A lot of scientists have come round to the view that radiofrequency radiation is probably carcinogenic because of new research that has emerged since 2011.”</p>
<p>That was the year the World Health Organization’s <a href="http://www.iarc.fr/en/media-centre/pr/2011/pdfs/pr208_E.pdf" target="_blank">International Agency for Research on Cancer</a> classified radiofrequency electromagnetic fields as “possibly carcinogenic to humans.” A panel of 31 expert scientists from 14 different countries concluded radiofrequency radiation, which is emitted by cell phones and other wireless communication devices should be placed in Group 2B alongside a fairly long list of other substances that includes lead, coffee, nickel, and gasoline.</p>
<p>But is it really so dangerous? Despite the passionate views espoused by many experts, others are confident that the risk is overblown, or at least reluctant to push for sweeping societal changes. So should you be afraid, or gab away as usual? We asked a few experts to find out the truth.</p>
<h3>Independent studies are showing danger</h3>
<p>Cell phone emissions were classified as “possibly carcinogenic” based on an increased risk of glioma, which is the most common form of brain cancer, but they were also strongly linked with another type of tumor, benign acoustic neuromas. A lot of the available evidence back in 2011 came from a series of studies known as the <a href="http://interphone.iarc.fr/" target="_blank">Interphone studies</a>, which were partly funded by the wireless communications industry.</p>
<div class="simplePullQuote right h-nonessential"><p>A panel of 31 expert scientists from 14 different countries classified radiofrequency electromagnetic fields as “possibly carcinogenic to humans.”</p>
</div>
<p>“I’ve been tracking the research for five years now and the evidence of the effect is growing stronger,” Moskowitz told Digital Trends. “This is perhaps in part because the new studies are independent, not funded by the wireless industry.”</p>
<p>Back in 2006, Henry Lai, a professor at the University of Washington analyzed all available studies on cell phone radiation from 1990 to 2006. He found that 50 percent of the 326 studies showed a biological effect from radio-frequency radiation, but when he divided them into independently funded studies and those funded by the wireless industry he found the split was 70 – 30.</p>
<p>“Even if you accept all the industry studies, you still end up with 50-50,” Lai told <a href="http://www.seattlemag.com/article/nerd-report/nerd-report" target="_blank">Seattle Mag</a> in 2011. “How could 50 percent all be garbage? People always start with the statement ‘hundreds of studies have been done on this topic, and no effect has been found’ — but this is a very misleading statement.”</p>
<p>Another potentially telling revelation is that the industry can’t get product liability insurance for mobile devices. Some people within the insurance industry feel that there’s a real risk of a wave of lawsuits related to brain tumors and other conditions caused by cell phones over the next couple of decades. Insurance giant the Swiss Re Group included “unforeseen consequences of electromagnetic fields” in its <a href="http://media.swissre.com/documents/SONAR_+Emerging_risk_insights_from_Swiss_Re.pdf" target="_blank">Emerging Risk Insights report</a>.</p>
<div class="dtads-inject-hook" style="display:none"></div>
<p>“Governments are flying blind on this, they’re either ignorant or they’re in denial,” Moskowitz says. “In part it’s ignorance, but in part they’re getting pressure from an industry that dwarfs big tobacco. It’s just too profitable, about a sixth of your cell phone bill in the U.S. goes to government in fees or taxes.”</p>
<p>Do we all have our heads in the sand? This is a controversial topic and it’s hard to get definitive answers. We decided to speak to Dr. Kurt Straif, Head of the World Health Organization program that classified RF electromagnetic fields as “possibly carcinogenic” back in 2011. And in Straif’s eyes, the situation is far muddier.</p>
<p>“We don’t know for sure if it’s causing cancer or not.”</p>
<p>“We’ve done almost 1,000 different agent assessments,” Dr. Straif told Digital Trends, “and this is probably the most heated controversy in terms of strong believers — scientists in the field that say we already know it’s causing cancer to the other extreme that says every additional cent spent on research is wasted because we know it can never cause cancer.”</p>
<p><a href="http://monographs.iarc.fr/" target="_blank">The IARC Monographs program</a> Straif headed up was formed with the backing of the World Health Organization and the United Nations, at the request of member states looking to identify substances and circumstances that are known to cause cancer in humans, and to make that information available for cancer prevention.</p>
<p>An independent advisory group suggests topics and the Monographs group decides what to pursue. It gathers all the published research, identifies the best experts in the world for each topic, and they draft working papers, and then there is an 8 day meeting to classify each possible carcinogen and create a volume of Monographs.</p>
<div id="attachment_753755" class="wp-caption aligncenter dt-caption-large" style="width: 640px"><img class="wp-image-753755 size-large" src="http://icdn4.digitaltrends.com/image/dr-dana-loomis-dr-kurt-straif-640x640.jpg" alt="IARC Section Head Dr. Kurt Straif and Deputy Section Head Dr. Dana Loomis "     /><div class="wp-caption-text"><p>Dr. Kurt Straif, left, led the World Health Organization program that classified cell phone radiation as “possibly carcinogenic to humans.”</p></div></div>
<p>“The Monographs are the most authoritative program in cancer-hazard identification, running for the longest time, looking at all types of environmental exposure, but also known for being the strongest program in terms of a very strict policy to exclude conflicts of interest,” Straif explains. “Scientists with a link to industry, or on the other hand, scientists with a very strong link to advocacy groups, would not be eligible to serve on the working group.”</p>
<p>He points out that, though the Interphone study was partly funded by industry, there was a very strict firewall in place overseen by the Union for International Cancer Control.</p>
<p>“I did not sense any strong orchestrated efforts by industry to influence the outcome of the 2011 meeting,” he told us.</p>
<p>We can safely say that the IARC group is impartial. It’s no stranger to controversy and it does not bend to big business. Take for example the recent classification of glyphosate — the main chemical in the pesticide Roundup — as “<a href="http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/roundup-ingredient-probably-carcinogenic-humans/" target="_blank">probably carcinogenic</a>,” a move that incurred the wrath of Monsanto, the pesticide’s maker. Glyphosate is in group 2A, which is still one step down from Group 1, “carcinogenic to humans.” Radiofrequency EMF radiation was placed in Group 2B, largely based on cell phone studies. So what does the “possibly carcinogenic” classification actually mean?</p>
<div id="attachment_753754" class="wp-caption alignright " style="width: 217px"><a  class="wp-image-753754" href="http://icdn2.digitaltrends.com/image/international-centre-for-research-on-cancer-iarc-1000x1500.jpg" style="width: 217px;"><span class="zoom-button"></span><img class="size-medium wp-image-753754" src="http://icdn5.digitaltrends.com/image/international-centre-for-research-on-cancer-iarc-325x325.jpg" alt="IARC"     /></a><div class="wp-caption-text"><p>The IARC, headquartered in Lyon, France, conducts research without funding from the wireless industry.</p></div><div class='m-image-credit' data-image-id='753754' >Wikipedia</div></div>
<p>“It means that there is scientific evidence, in this case limited evidence from the human studies, that it could cause cancer in humans,” says Straif. “There is also limited evidence from animal studies, and there is weak mechanistic data. These three things together result in the evaluation of possibly carcinogenic.”</p>
<p>There is currently no firm plan to reassess radiofrequency EMF radiation, but Dr. Straif says it is on the radar, and if important new evidence was to emerge, the IARC Monographs group could make it a priority.</p>
<p>“Knowing about the studies that have been published since 2011, I think that the epidemiological evidence is still limited,” says Straif, making it clear that this is his personal opinion and not that of the IARC group. “It has not changed in the one or the other direction. There are lots of different scientific groups out there. Some think with the new publications that the human evidence is now sufficient to result in a Group 1 classification as a known human carcinogen. I don’t think these studies would change the current overall evaluation of 2B.”</p>
<p><strong>Next page: Are you more likely to get cancer? If so, how much more?</strong></p>

So what does the \u201cpossibly carcinogenic\u201d classification actually mean?<\/p>\n<div id=\"attachment_753754\" class=\"wp-caption alignright \" style=\"width: 217px\"><a  class=\"wp-image-753754\" href=\"http:\/\/icdn2.digitaltrends.com\/image\/international-centre-for-research-on-cancer-iarc-1000x1500.jpg\" style=\"width: 217px;\"><span class=\"zoom-button\"><\/span><img class=\"size-medium wp-image-753754\" src=\"http:\/\/icdn5.digitaltrends.com\/image\/international-centre-for-research-on-cancer-iarc-325x325.jpg\" alt=\"IARC\"     \/><\/a><div class=\"wp-caption-text\"><p>The IARC, headquartered in Lyon, France, conducts research without funding from the wireless industry.<\/p><\/div><div class='m-image-credit' data-image-id='753754' >Wikipedia<\/div><\/div>\n<p>\u201cIt means that there is scientific evidence, in this case limited evidence from the human studies, that it could cause cancer in humans,\u201d says\u00a0Straif. \u201cThere is also limited evidence from animal studies, and there is weak mechanistic data. These three things together result in the evaluation of possibly carcinogenic.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>There is currently no firm plan to reassess radiofrequency EMF radiation, but Dr. Straif says it is on the radar, and if important new evidence was to emerge, the IARC Monographs group could make it a priority.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cKnowing about the studies that have been published since 2011, I think that the epidemiological evidence is still limited,\u201d says Straif, making it clear that this is his personal opinion and not that of\u00a0the IARC group. \u201cIt has not changed in the one or the other direction. There are lots of different scientific groups out there. I don’t think these studies would change the current overall evaluation of 2B.\u201d<\/p>\n<p><strong>Next page:\u00a0Are you more likely to get cancer? If so, how much more?<\/strong><\/p>\n","title":"Independent studies are showing danger"},{"page":2,"url":"http:\/\/www.digitaltrends.com\/mobile\/can-cell-phones-cause-brain-cancer\/2\/","html":"\n<h3>How much could\u00a0smartphones increase your risk of brain cancer?<\/h3>\n<p>\u201cIt has been understood since 1975 that very low intensity exposure to microwave radiation can open the blood\/brain barrier. It evolved to keep larger molecules out of the brain tissue,\u201d explains Moskowitz. \u201cMost people nowadays have around 100 toxins in their blood system at any point in time. Some of those toxins may be able to penetrate brain tissue in the presence of low intensity exposure like Wi-Fi, cell phones, cell towers, wireless baby monitors, and wireless smart meters.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Still, it’s difficult to put the risks into context.<\/p>\n<p>It’s worth mentioning that radiofrequency electromagentic fields aren’t just the product of cell phones. Straif explained that Wi-Fi and Bluetooth are in the same category, but most of the evidence they were able to draw on for the IARC classification of “possibly carcinogenic” came from cell phone studies.<\/p>\n<div class=\"dtads-inject-hook\" style=\"display:none\"><\/div>\n<p>\u201cIf you think in terms of levels of exposure from Wi-Fi or Bluetooth, these are orders of magnitude lower,\u201d Straif said. \u201cEven if there is a risk, it would be much lower.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Swedish oncologist Dr. Lennart Hardell is convinced of the carcinogenic effect and is one of the few researchers to have conducted long-term <a href=\"http:\/\/www.pathophysiologyjournal.com\/article\/S0928-4680(14)00064-9\/abstract\" target=\"_blank\">independent\u00a0studies<\/a>. He suggests that the risk of developing brain cancer is three times higher after 25 years of cell phone use. But what does that actually mean?<\/p>\n<p>According to the\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/seer.cancer.gov\/archive\/csr\/1975_2010\/\" target=\"_blank\">National Cancer Institute<\/a>, 5 out of 100,000 Americans under the age of 65 were diagnosed with brain cancer between 2006 and 2010, which puts your chances at about 0.005 percent. If this rate tripled,\u00a0it would make it\u00a015 out of every 100,000, bumping your chance up to 0.015 percent.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThe risk of brain cancer after 10 years is roughly doubled,\u201d says Moskowitz. \u201cStudies have shown that the risk of tumor development is on the side of the head where the phone is predominantly used.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>The <a href=\"http:\/\/www.abta.org\/\" target=\"_blank\">American Brain Tumor Association<\/a> put us in touch with Dr. Barnholtz-Sloan at Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine. He downplayed a causal link between brain cancer and cell phones.<\/p>\n<div class=\"simplePullQuote right h-nonessential\"><p>Dr. Lennart Hardell suggests that the risk of developing brain cancer is three times higher after 25 years of cell phone use.<\/p>\n<\/div>\n<p>“I would love it if we found a risk factor for brain tumors like smoking for lung cancer, so we could advise patients and their families,” says Dr. Barnholtz-Sloan.\u00a0“But we haven’t found one yet.”<\/p>\n<p>The <a href=\"http:\/\/globocan.iarc.fr\/old\/FactSheets\/cancers\/lung-new.asp\" target=\"_blank\">IARC<\/a> puts incidences of lung cancer at around 40 out of 100,000 for Northern America. The latest data from the <a href=\"http:\/\/www.cbtrus.org\/\" target=\"_blank\">Central Brain Tumor Registry of the United States<\/a> puts the incidence rate for newly diagnosed malignant brain tumors in the U.S. at 7.25 per 100,000. The official definition of a rare cancer in the U.S. is anything that affects fewer than 15 out of 100,000 people each year.<\/p>\n<p>“The current evidence about the association between using cell phones and brain tumor risk is inconclusive,” Barnholtz-Sloan told us. “Some studies have shown positive associations and some have shown negative results. The studies with positive associations show a risk of 1.5 to 2.0, which is small in comparison to the relationship between smoking and lung cancer, hence multiple other factors must be involved to explain the risk of a brain tumor. With the uptake of cell phones over the last 20 years, if cell phones were truly a major risk factor for brain tumors we would have expected an increase in brain tumor diagnoses, but the diagnosis rates are relatively stable.”<\/p>\n<div id=\"attachment_753781\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter dt-caption-large\" style=\"width: 640px\"><a  class=\"wp-image-753781\" href=\"http:\/\/icdn3.digitaltrends.com\/image\/dr-barnholtz-sloan-704x470.jpg\" style=\"width: 640px;\"><span class=\"zoom-button\"><\/span><img class=\"wp-image-753781 size-large\" src=\"http:\/\/icdn6.digitaltrends.com\/image\/dr-barnholtz-sloan-640x640.jpg\" alt=\"Dr. Barnholtz-Sloan\"     \/><\/a><div class=\"wp-caption-text\"><p>Dr. Barnholtz-Sloan at Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine believes the current evidence on cell phones increasing the risk of cancer is inconclusive.<\/p><\/div><\/div>\n<p>It’s hard to know how worried we should be about these risks. We aren’t seeing the kind of obvious correlation that there is between smoking and lung cancer, for example, where the\u00a0CDC\u00a0estimates smokers are 15 to 30 times more likely to get lung cancer than non-smokers. But we also don’t have as much research to draw on for cell phone exposure, and we know that usage is climbing dramatically. Many of us plan to use cell phones for the next 50 years or longer. It would be nice to know that they’re safe.<\/p>\n<p>“I think the results are inconclusive,” says Dr. Barnholtz-Sloan. “Which, in my view, mean’s that the jury’s still out.”<\/p>\n<h3>The official position<\/h3>\n<p>Despite years of research, it seems we still don’t really know for sure whether cell phones cause cancer. Many official agencies make it clear that no link has been proven, but they go out of their way not to rule it out.<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>FCC<\/strong>:\u00a0The\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.fcc.gov\/encyclopedia\/faqs-wireless-phones\" target=\"_blank\">FCC<\/a>\u00a0says \u201cthere is no scientific evidence that proves that wireless phone usage can lead to cancer or a variety of other problems, including headaches, dizziness, or memory loss. However, organizations in the United States and overseas are sponsoring research and investigating claims of possible health effects related to the use of wireless telephones.\u201d<\/li>\n<li><strong>CDC<\/strong>:\u00a0The\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.cdc.gov\/nceh\/radiation\/cell_phones._FAQ.html\" target=\"_blank\">CDC<\/a>\u00a0claims \u201cthere is no scientific evidence that provides a definite answer to that question [Can using a cell phone cause cancer?]. Some organizations recommend caution in cell phone use. More research is needed before we know if using cell phones causes health effects.\u201d<\/li>\n<li><strong>National Cancer Institute<\/strong>:\u00a0The\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.cancer.gov\/cancertopics\/causes-prevention\/risk\/radiation\/cell-phones-fact-sheet\" target=\"_blank\">National Cancer Institute<\/a>\u00a0says that \u201cstudies thus far have not shown a consistent link between cell phone use and cancers of the brain, nerves, or other tissues of the head or neck. More research is needed because cell phone technology and how people use cell phones have been changing rapidly.\u201d<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>More health dangers from phones<\/h3>\n<p>“This is a snapshot of what we know now,\u201d says Straif, adding \u201cwhat we know now is not necessarily the full picture.\u201d\u00a0With tobacco, the only clear evidence early on linked it to lung cancer, but every time it was reassessed, additional cancer sites were added. This won’t necessarily be the case for cell phones, but it’s possible.<\/p>\n<p>Brain cancer is not the only risk that has been associated with prolonged cell phone use. There have been studies linking it with tumors in\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/aje.oxfordjournals.org\/content\/167\/4\/457.full\" target=\"_blank\">salivary glands<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\/pmc\/articles\/PMC3243874\/\" target=\"_blank\">thyroid glands<\/a>. There’s increasing evidence of a link with neurological disorders and neurodegenerative effects, and it may negatively affect\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.exeter.ac.uk\/news\/featurednews\/title_385859_en.html\" target=\"_blank\">fertility<\/a>. Some scientists have even suggested that the increase in cases of\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\/pubmed\/23555766\" target=\"_blank\">ADHD<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.next-up.org\/pdf\/AutismAustralasianCollegeOfTheNutritionalAndEnvironmentalMedicineACNEMfina102007.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">autism<\/a>\u00a0could be related to the rise in cell phone use.<\/p>\n<div class=\"dtads-inject-hook\" style=\"display:none\"><\/div>\n<p>A growing number of people are also self-diagnosing\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Electromagnetic_hypersensitivity\" target=\"_blank\">electromagnetic hypersensitivity<\/a>, which is associated with a long list of symptoms and supposedly triggered by proximity to cell phones and other electromagnetic fields. It’s not a recognized medical condition, and there have been double blind studies with\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov\/pubmed\/21793784\" target=\"_blank\">positive<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.bmj.com\/content\/332\/7546\/886.full\" target=\"_blank\">negative<\/a>\u00a0results.<\/p>\n<p>Whether it’s a real condition or not, sufferers certainly believe it is real.\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/www.popsci.com\/achieve-radio-silence-west-virginia-town\" target=\"_blank\">Popular Science<\/a>\u00a0just ran an interesting piece on the town of Green Bank, West Virginia where there’s a growing electrosensitive community who’ve moved there because the town is in the heart of the\u00a0<a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/United_States_National_Radio_Quiet_Zone\" target=\"_blank\">National Radio Quiet Zone<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Next page: Is the tech getting safer? How to protect yourself<\/strong><\/p>\n","title":"How much could\u00a0smartphones increase your risk of brain cancer?"},{"page":3,"url":"http:\/\/www.digitaltrends.com\/mobile\/can-cell-phones-cause-brain-cancer\/3\/","html":"\n<h3>But the technology is getting safer, right?<\/h3>\n<p>“We know that with the new technology, the third and fourth generation, the exposure, in terms of non-ionizing radiation, has reduced by an order of magnitude,\u201d Straif told Digital Trends. \u201cThe overall trend for exposure per minute has reduced since [the original studies, such as the Interphone study, which ended in 2006]. However, at the same time, probably the talk time on the phone for the average person has increased.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Moskowitz disagrees.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWe have no indication that 3G or 4G is any safer and, in fact, the preliminary research on both suggests that it may be more harmful.\u201d he says.<\/p>\n<p>Part of the issue is that the standards that are currently in place to govern radiofrequency emissions were never designed with cell phones in mind.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThe current federal standards and international guidelines are way too high because they were only developed to protect against thermal effects, yet most of the studies are showing non-thermal effects,\u201d says Moskowitz. \u201cThey clearly should be revisited. Many experts have called for such a review and that effort continues.\u201d<\/p>\n<div class=\"dtads-inject-hook\" style=\"display:none\"><\/div>\n<p>You can check the SAR (Specific Absorption Rate) rating for your phone. Manufacturers have to publish this information publicly. Here is\u00a0Apple’s <a href=\"https:\/\/www.apple.com\/legal\/rfexposure\/iphone7,2\/en\/\" target=\"_blank\">RF exposure data\u00a0for the iPhone 6<\/a> as an example. It tells you about the amount of radiation being absorbed into your body when use the device.<\/p>\n<p>Some countries are taking the threat more seriously than others. Belgium passed legislation that forces the manufacturer and retailer to prominently display the SAR value of each device. The country\u00a0has also banned the sale or advertising of cell phones for children aged 7 and under. France recently passed\u00a0similar laws\u00a0including a ban on Wi-Fi in nursery schools and introducing restrictions in schools for children up to the age of 11.<\/p>\n<h3>What can you do if you’re worried?<\/h3>\n<p>\u201cIf you are concerned, and you want to take some steps to reduce your exposure, there are easy ways to do that,\u201d says Straif. \u201cFor example, using a hands-free kit, which drastically lowers the exposure to the brain, or talking less over the phone.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>There are a few obvious precautions you can take if you want to reduce your exposure and risk, but they mostly amount to not using your phone.<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li>Limit the amount of time you use your phone<\/li>\n<li>Don’t keep your phone next to the bed at night<\/li>\n<li>Turn Airplane mode on or turn your phone off when you don’t need it<\/li>\n<li>Don’t carry your phone close to your body<\/li>\n<li>Don’t hold it to your head, use a headset for calls instead<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p>\u201cReducing our exposure considerably is feasible and would probably do a lot to reduce the public health burden,\u201d says Moskowitz. He has <a href=\"http:\/\/www.saferemr.com\/2015\/03\/some-tips-to-reduce-your-exposure-to.html\" target=\"_blank\">a one-page\u00a0tip sheet<\/a>\u00a0offering more advice.<\/p>\n<h3>Future research and answers<\/h3>\n<p>“What we really need is better epidemiological studies,\u201d says Straif. \u201cIdeally cohort studies that go from the exposure to the cancer, instead of case control studies where we select people with cancer and controls, and try to assess their exposure retroactively. Such cohort studies could, for example, make use of the objective data from service providers about the usage of mobile phones, so we would get a much better picture of the actual usage. These studies are in the pipeline, but they take a long time.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>For some people that evidence can’t come fast enough.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cPeople love these devices. They’re great devices for a variety of reasons; People don’t want to believe that they could possibly cause them harm,\u201d says Moskowitz. \u201cThe public health establishment in the U.S. is also in denial, but it’s just a matter of time before this issue comes back to bite us.\u201d<\/p>\n","title":"But the technology is getting safer, right?"}]}</script>
